oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Forage
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Application of James Lillard claiming payment due for Quartermaster's stores or subsistence supplies. Lillard claims that one hundred bushels of corn, 16,000 pounds of hay, 12,000 feet of plank, and five grey mares were taken by the U. S. Army during the war, at a combined value of $812.00.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: United States -- Army -- Quartermaster's Dept.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The U. S. Army relied heavily on impressed goods while on campaign. While the Quartermaster furnished rations and other goods for the army, many items, such as horses, mules, wood, and animal feed, were often taken from local populations. The U. S. government promised to reimburse individuals for impressed items through January 1, 1880, after which no further claims would be accepted.
